hebrew_text: מַשְׁקִין בֵּית הַשְּׁלָחִין בַּמּוֹעֵד וּבַשְּׁבִיעִית, בֵּין מִמַּעְיָין שֶׁיָּצָא בַּתְּחִילָּה, בֵּין מִמַּעְיָין שֶׁלֹּא יָצָא בַּתְּחִילָּה. אֲבָל אֵין מַשְׁקִין לֹא מִמֵּי הַגְּשָׁמִים, וְלֹא מִמֵּי הַקִּילוֹן.
human_translation: One may irrigate a field that requires irrigation on a Festival as well as during the Sabbatical Year, both from a newly emerged spring and from a spring that did not just emerge However, one may not irrigate with rainwater or with water drawn with a shadoof [ kilon ],
llm_translation: We water the Beit HaShelachin on the festival and on the seventh year, whether from the spring that initially flowed or from a spring that did not initially flow. However, we do not water it neither from rainwater nor from water of the Kilon.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין עוֹשִׂין עוּגִיּוֹת לַגְּפָנִים. רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה אוֹמֵר: אֵין עוֹשִׂין אֶת הָאַמָּה בַּתְּחִילָּה בַּמּוֹעֵד וּבִשְׁבִיעִית, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: עוֹשִׂין אֶת הָאַמָּה בַּתְּחִילָּה בַּשְּׁבִיעִית, וּמְתַקְּנִין אֶת הַמְקוּלְקָלוֹת בַּמּוֹעֵד.
human_translation: And one may not construct circular ditches grapevines Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says: One may not construct a new channel during a Festival or during the Sabbatical Year. And the Rabbis say: One may construct a new channel during the Sabbatical Year and one may repair damaged during a Festival.
llm_translation: They do not make cakes for the vineyards. Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah says: They do not make the 'Amah at the beginning of the festival and in the seventh year, and the sages say: They make the 'Amah at the beginning of the seventh year, and they repair the damaged fences during the festival.

hebrew_text: וּמְתַקְּנִין אֶת קִלְקוּלֵי הַמַּיִם שֶׁבִּרְשׁוּת הָרַבִּים, וְחוֹטְטִין אוֹתָן, וּמְתַקְּנִין אֶת הַדְּרָכִים וְאֶת הָרְחוֹבוֹת וְאֶת מִקְווֹת הַמַּיִם, וְעוֹשִׂין כׇּל צוֹרְכֵי הָרַבִּים, וּמְצַיְּינִין אֶת הַקְּבָרוֹת, וְיוֹצְאִין אַף עַל הַכִּלְאַיִם.
human_translation: One may repair damaged water that are in the public domain, and clean them out one may repair roads, streets, and ritual baths; and one may tend to all public needs. one may mark graves and may even go out to the diverse kinds kilayim ]
llm_translation: And they repair the leaks of the water in the public domain, and they patch them, and they repair the roads and the streets and the water channels, and they fulfill all the needs of the public, and they mark the graves, and they go out even on Shabbat.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ הַשְׁתָּא יֵשׁ לוֹמַר מִמַּעְיָין שֶׁיָּצָא בַּתְּחִילָּה, דְּאָתֵי לְאִינְּפוֹלֵי — מַשְׁקִין, מִמַּעְיָין שֶׁלֹּא יָצָא בַּתְּחִילָּה, דְּלָא אָתֵי לְאִינְּפוֹלֵי — מִיבַּעְיָא?
human_translation: Now it has been said one may irrigate from a newly emerged spring, likely to collapse, is it necessary from a spring that did not just emerge, and are not likely to collapse?
llm_translation: Gemara: Now, this one can say from a spring that initially emerged, for it comes to be poured out - liquids, from a spring that did not initially emerge, for it does not come to be poured out - what is the question?

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי, אִצְטְרִיךְ: אִי תַּנָּא מַעְיָין שֶׁיָּצָא בַּתְּחִילָּה, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: הָכָא הוּא דְּבֵית הַשְּׁלָחִין — אִין, בֵּית הַבַּעַל — לָא, מִשּׁוּם דְּאָתֵי לְאִינְּפוֹלֵי. אֲבָל מַעְיָין שֶׁלֹּא יָצָא בַּתְּחִילָּה, דְּלָא אָתֵי לְאִינְּפוֹלֵי — אֵימָא אֲפִילּוּ בֵּית הַבַּעַל נָמֵי,
human_translation: They say it was necessary had taught a newly emerged spring, I would have said here, a field that requires irrigation, yes, a field that suffices with rainwater, no, because it is likely to collapse. But a spring that did not just emerge, that is not likely to collapse, I say that even a field that suffices with rainwater.
llm_translation: They said, it is necessary: if the spring initially flows, I would have said: here, in the house of the privy — no, in the house of the husband — yes, because it is likely to collapse. But if the spring does not initially flow, as it is not likely to collapse — say, even in the house of the husband also.

hebrew_text: קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן: לָא שְׁנָא מַעְיָין שֶׁיָּצָא בַּתְּחִילָּה, וְלָא שְׁנָא מַעְיָין שֶׁלֹּא יָצָא בַּתְּחִילָּה, בֵּית הַשְּׁלָחִין — אִין, בֵּית הַבַּעַל — לָא.
human_translation: teaches us a newly emerged spring is no different a spring that did not just emerge. a field that requires irrigation, yes, a field that suffices with rainwater, no,
llm_translation: We have learned: A spring that did not flow initially is no different from a spring that did flow initially. Regarding a latrine - no, regarding a bathhouse - yes.

hebrew_text: וּמַאי מַשְׁמַע דְּהַאי ״בֵּית הַשְּׁלָחִין״ לִישָּׁנָא דְּצָחוּתָא הִיא — דִּכְתִיב: ״וְאַתָּה עָיֵף וְיָגֵעַ״, וּמְתַרְגְּמִינַן: וְאַתְּ מְשַׁלְהֵי וּלְאֵי.
human_translation: And from where be inferred that this beit hashelaḥin , is a term thirst, As it is written: “And you were faint and weary” And, we translate And you were thirsty [ meshalhei ] and weary.
llm_translation: "And what is implied by this, that 'Beit HaShelachin' is for the sleep of the righteous? - For it is written: 'And you are weary and fatigued,' and we interpret: 'And you are lying down and not rising up.'"

hebrew_text: וּמַאי מַשְׁמַע דְּהַאי ״בֵּית הַבַּעַל״ לִישָּׁנָא דִּמְיַיתְּבוּתָא הִיא — דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּי יִבְעַל בָּחוּר בְּתוּלָה״, וּמְתַרְגְּמִינַן: אֲרֵי כַּמָּה דְּמִיתּוֹתַב עוּלֵם עִם בְּתוּלְתָּא יִתְיַיתְּבוּן בְּגַוִּיךְ בְּנַיִיךְ.
human_translation: And from where be inferred that this beit haba’al , is a term denoting settlement, As it is written: “For as a young man takes to himself [ yiv’al ] a virgin, And it is translated As a young man settles down with a virgin, so shall your sons become settled within you.
llm_translation: And what is implied by this, that this "house of the husband" is like a settled matter? - For it is written: "When a man marries a virgin," and we interpret: Behold, just as the world existed with the virgin, so too should you establish your sons with your daughters.

hebrew_text: מַאן תַּנָּא דִּפְסֵידָא — אִין, הַרְוָוחָה — לָא, וַאֲפִילּוּ בִּמְקוֹם פְּסֵידָא — מִיטְרָח נָמֵי לָא טָרְחִינַן?
human_translation: Who is the tanna that loss, yes, profit, no, even in a case loss, one may not exert
llm_translation: Who is the Tanna that says "Dipseda" - No, "Harvacha" - Yes, and even in a place of "Dipseda" we do not require to exert ourselves?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב הִיא. דִּתְנַן, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב אוֹמֵר: מוֹשְׁכִין אֶת הַמַּיִם מֵאִילָן לְאִילָן, וּבִלְבַד שֶׁלֹּא יַשְׁקֶה אֶת הַשָּׂדֶה כּוּלָּהּ.
human_translation: Rav Huna said: It is Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, as we learned Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: one may draw water from tree to tree, provided that he does not water the entire field.
llm_translation: Rav Huna said: Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov is it. As we learned in a Mishnah, Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says: One may draw water from one tree to another, as long as he does not water the entire field.

hebrew_text: אֵימוֹר דְּשָׁמְעַתְּ לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר הַרְוָוחָה דְּלָא, טִירְחָא בִּמְקוֹם פְּסֵידָא מִי שָׁמְעַתְּ לֵיהּ?
human_translation: Say that you heard Rabbi Eliezer profit is not did you hear him exertion in a case of loss?
llm_translation: Tractate: Eimor d'sham'at leih l'Rabbi Eliezer harvacha d'la, tircha bimkom p'seida mi sham'at leih?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: הָא מַנִּי — רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, דְּתַנְיָא: מַעְיָין הַיּוֹצֵא בַּתְּחִילָּה — מַשְׁקִין מִמֶּנּוּ אֲפִילּוּ שְׂדֵה בֵּית הַבַּעַל, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אֵין מַשְׁקִין אֶלָּא שְׂדֵה בֵּית הַשְּׁלָחִין שֶׁחָרְבָה. רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה אוֹמֵר: לֹא כָּךְ וְלֹא כָּךְ. יָתֵר עַל כֵּן אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה: לֹא יַפְנֶה אָדָם אַמַּת הַמַּיִם וְיַשְׁקֶה לְגִינָּתוֹ וּלְחוּרְבָּתוֹ בְּחוּלּוֹ שֶׁל מוֹעֵד.
human_translation: Rather, Rav Pappa said: whose is this It is Rabbi Yehuda, as it is taught From a newly emerged spring one may irrigate even a field that suffices with rainwater; the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: One may irrigate only a field requiring irrigation that dried up Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says: Neither the one nor the other. Furthermore, Rabbi Yehuda said: one may not divert a water channel to water his garden or his ruin, during the intermediate days of a Festival.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rather, Rav Papa said: This is the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, as it was taught: If a spring emerges initially, one may draw water from it even for the fields of a husband's house, according to the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: One may only draw water for the fields of a courtyard that has been plowed. Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah says: Not like this and not like this. Therefore, Rabbi Yehuda said: A person should not divert a cubit of water and use it to water his garden and his courtyard on a weekday of the festival.

hebrew_text: מַאי ״חָרְבָה״? אִילֵּימָא חָרְבָה מַמָּשׁ, לְמָה לִי דְּמַשְׁקֵי לַהּ? אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: שֶׁחָרְבָה מִמַּעְיָין זֶה וְיָצָא לָהּ מַעְיָין אַחֵר.
human_translation: What is dried up? If we say literally dried up why do I to water it? Abaye said: the one spring dried up, but another spring emerged.
llm_translation: What is "Charvah"? Perhaps it is an actual sword, why do I need Damascus for it? Abaye said: Charvah is from this spring and another spring emerged for it.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה אוֹמֵר לֹא כָּךְ וְלֹא כָּךְ, לָא שְׁנָא חָרַב מַעְיָינָהּ וְלָא שְׁנָא לֹא חָרַב מַעְיָינָהּ — מַעְיָין שֶׁיָּצָא בַּתְּחִילָּה לָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says: Neither the one nor the other. it is no different the spring dried up or did not dry up. a newly emerged spring not
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah says: Not like this and not like this, whether it was destroyed from the outset or not destroyed from the outset - a spring that did not initially flow forth.

hebrew_text: וּמִמַּאי? דִּלְמָא עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה: בֵּית הַשְּׁלָחִין — אִין, בֵּית הַבַּעַל — לָא, אֶלָּא מַעְיָין שֶׁיָּצָא בַּתְּחִילָּה
human_translation: And from where Perhaps Rabbi Yehuda stated a field that requires irrigation, yes, a field that suffices with rainwater, no, only a newly emerged spring,
llm_translation: "And from where? Perhaps until here Rabbi Yehuda did not say: Beit HaShelachin - no, Beit HaBa'al - no, rather a spring that flowed initially."

hebrew_text: דִּלְמָא אָתֵי לְאִינְּפוֹלֵי. אֲבָל מַעְיָין שֶׁלֹּא יָצָא בַּתְּחִילָּה, דְּלָא אָתֵי לְאִינְּפוֹלֵי — אֲפִילּוּ בֵּית הַבַּעַל נָמֵי!
human_translation: as it is likely to collapse. But a spring that did not just emerge, which is not likely to collapse even a field that suffices with rainwater
llm_translation: Perhaps he will come to fall. But a spring that did not initially flow, that it will not come to fall - even the house of the owner is near!

hebrew_text: אִם כֵּן — מַתְנִיתִין אַמַּאן תִּרְמְיַיהּ? אֶלָּא: לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה לָא שְׁנָא מַעְיָין שֶׁיָּצָא בַּתְּחִילָּה, וְלָא שְׁנָא מַעְיָין שֶׁלֹּא יָצָא בַּתְּחִילָּה, בֵּית הַשְּׁלָחִין — אִין, בֵּית הַבַּעַל — לָא. וְהַאי דְּקָתָנֵי מַעְיָין שֶׁיָּצָא בַּתְּחִילָּה, לְהוֹדִיעֲךָ כֹּחוֹ דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר, דַּאֲפִילּוּ מַעְיָין הַיּוֹצֵא בַּתְּחִילָּה — מַשְׁקִין מִמֶּנּוּ אֲפִילּוּ שְׂדֵה הַבַּעַל.
human_translation: If so, to whom, would you attribute Rather, Rabbi Yehuda, a newly emerged spring is no different a spring that did not just emerge. A field that requires irrigation, yes, a field that suffices with rainwater, no, And to teach a newly emerged spring to convey the far-reaching nature of of Rabbi Meir, one may irrigate even from a newly emerged spring, even a field that suffices with rainwater.
llm_translation: If so - Mishnah says: where do you draw the line? Rather, according to Rabbi Yehuda, it does not matter if the spring initially emerged, and it does not matter if the spring did not initially emerge, in the house of the senders - no, in the house of the owners - yes. And this that it teaches that if the spring initially emerged, it is to inform you of the power of Rabbi Meir, that even if the spring that emerges initially - they water from it even the field of the owner.

hebrew_text: אִתְּמַר: הַמְנַכֵּשׁ וְהַמַּשְׁקֶה מַיִם לִזְרָעִים בְּשַׁבָּת, מִשּׁוּם מַאי מַתְרִינַן בֵּיהּ? רַבָּה אָמַר: מִשּׁוּם חוֹרֵשׁ. רַב יוֹסֵף אָמַר: מִשּׁוּם זוֹרֵעַ.
human_translation: It was stated one who weeds or one who waters seedlings on Shabbat, for what do we forewarn him? Rabba said: due to plowing. Rav Yosef said: due to sowing.
llm_translation: It was stated: One who digs furrows and waters seeds on Shabbat, what is the reason that we permit him? Rabba said: Because of plowing. Rav Yosef said: Because of sowing.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה, כְּווֹתִי דִּידִי מִסְתַּבְּרָא: מָה דַּרְכּוֹ שֶׁל חוֹרֵשׁ — לְרַפּוֹיֵי אַרְעָא, הַאי נָמֵי מְרַפֵּויי אַרְעָא. אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף, כְּווֹתִי דִּידִי מִסְתַּבְּרָא: מָה דַּרְכּוֹ שֶׁל זוֹרֵעַ — לְצַמּוֹחֵי פֵּירָא, הָכָא נָמֵי מְצַמַּח פֵּירָא.
human_translation: Rabba said: According to my opinion is reasonable. Just as the of plowing is to loosen the earth, so too, this, loosens the earth. Rav Yosef said: According to my is reasonable. Just as the of sowing is to cause the fruit to grow, here too, causes the fruit to grow.
llm_translation: Rabba said, "My colleagues, my reasoning is as follows: Just as the way of a plower is to loosen the soil, so too here, it is loosening the soil." Rav Yosef said, "My colleagues, my reasoning is as follows: Just as the way of a sower is to cause fruit to grow, so too here, it is causing the fruit to grow."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי לְרַבָּה: לְדִידָךְ קַשְׁיָא וּלְרַב יוֹסֵף קַשְׁיָא. לְדִידָךְ קַשְׁיָא: מִשּׁוּם חוֹרֵשׁ אִין, מִשּׁוּם זוֹרֵעַ לָא? לְרַב יוֹסֵף קַשְׁיָא: מִשּׁוּם זוֹרֵעַ אִין, מִשּׁוּם חוֹרֵשׁ לָא?
human_translation: Abaye said to Rabba: According to your difficult, and according to Rav Yosef, difficult. According to your difficult: for plowing, yes, for sowing, no, according to Rav Yosef, it difficult: for sowing, yes, for plowing, no,
llm_translation: Abaye said to Rava: According to your opinion it is problematic, and according to Rav Yosef's opinion it is problematic. According to your opinion it is problematic: Is it not due to the one who plows, and not due to the one who sows? According to Rav Yosef's opinion it is problematic: Is it not due to the one who sows, and not due to the one who plows?

hebrew_text: וְכִי תֵּימָא: כׇּל הֵיכָא דְּאִיכָּא תַּרְתֵּי לָא מִיחַיַּיב אֶלָּא חֲדָא, וְהָאָמַר רַב כָּהֲנָא: זוֹמֵר וְצָרִיךְ לָעֵצִים — חַיָּיב שְׁתַּיִם. אַחַת מִשּׁוּם נוֹטֵעַ, וְאַחַת מִשּׁוּם קוֹצֵר.
human_translation: And if you say that anywhere that there are two one is liable for only one didn’t Rav Kahana say: one prunes and he needs the wood he is liable two one for sowing, And one for reaping,
llm_translation: And if you will say: wherever there are two, one is not liable, but only one, and Rav Kahana said: one who prunes and needs the wood - is liable for two. One for planting, and one for cutting.

hebrew_text: קַשְׁיָא.
human_translation: difficult
llm_translation: "Kashya."

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רַב יוֹסֵף לְרַבָּה: הַמְנַכֵּשׁ וְהַמְחַפֶּה לְכִלְאַיִם לוֹקֶה. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: אַף הַמְקַיֵּים.
human_translation: Rav Yosef raised an objection to Rabba One who weeds or covers diverse kinds, is flogged Rabbi Akiva says: Even one who maintains
llm_translation: He raised an objection to him, Rav Yosef to Rabah: One who sets a trap and one who covers it, for two animals, is liable. Rabbi Akiva says: Also one who maintains it.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְדִידִי, דְּאָמֵינָא מִשּׁוּם זוֹרֵעַ — הַיְינוּ דַּאֲסִירָא זְרִיעָה בְּכִלְאַיִם, אֶלָּא לְדִידָךְ, דְּאָמְרַתְּ מִשּׁוּם חוֹרֵשׁ — חֲרִישָׁה בְּכִלְאַיִם מִי אֲסִירָא?
human_translation: Granted, according to my that I say for sowing, this is Sowing diverse kinds is prohibited. But according to you, who said for plowing, Is plowing prohibited diverse kinds?
llm_translation: In truth, according to my opinion, that I say in the name of one who sows — that is, it is prohibited to sow in a mixture. But according to your opinion, that you say in the name of one who plows — is plowing in a mixture prohibited?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִשּׁוּם מְקַיֵּים.
human_translation: said to him: for maintaining
llm_translation: He said to him: in the name of the one who fulfills.

hebrew_text: וְהָא מִדְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא: רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר אַף הַמְקַיֵּים, מִכְּלָל דְּתַנָּא קַמָּא לָאו מִשּׁוּם מְקַיֵּים הוּא!
human_translation: However, from that it teaches in the latter clause Rabbi Akiva says: Even one who maintains it may be inferred that the first tanna , not for maintaining
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection from the latter clause: Rabbi Akiva says, "Even one who upholds the commandments, is he not included in the category of one who upholds the commandments!"

hebrew_text: כּוּלַּהּ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא הִיא, וּ״מַאי טַעַם״ קָאָמַר: מַאי טַעַם הַמְנַכֵּשׁ וְהַמְחַפֶּה בְּכִלְאַיִם לוֹקֶה מִשּׁוּם מְקַיֵּים — שֶׁרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: אַף הַמְקַיֵּים.
human_translation: the entire Rabbi Akiva, and it is stated what is the reason. What is the reason that one who weeds and one who covers diverse kinds is flogged? for maintaining as Rabbi Akiva says: Even one who maintains
llm_translation: The entire statement is attributed to Rabbi Akiva, and "what is the reason" he said: What is the reason that one who traps and covers an animal in a cage is liable to pay damages for fulfilling the prohibition of trapping? - Because Rabbi Akiva says: The verse states "even the one who fulfills the prohibition."

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא? דְּתַנְיָא: ״שָׂדְךָ לֹא תִזְרַע כִּלְאָיִם״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא זוֹרֵעַ, מְקַיֵּים מִנַּיִין?
human_translation: What is the reason Rabbi Akiva’s As it is taught “You shall not sow your field with mingled seed” I have only sowing From where maintaining
llm_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi Akiva's opinion? As it was taught: "You shall not sow your field with two kinds of seed," I have only this one who sows, how do I establish the count?

hebrew_text: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כִּלְאַיִם שָׂדְךָ לֹא״.
human_translation: The verse states: “Diverse kinds, you shall not your field
llm_translation: The Talmud teaches: "Like two kidneys your field not."

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: מַשְׁקִין בֵּית הַשְּׁלָחִין בַּמּוֹעֵד וּבִשְׁבִיעִית.
human_translation: We learned One may irrigate a field that requires irrigation on a Festival as well as during the Sabbatical Year.
llm_translation: We learned in the Mishnah: One may water the Beit HaShelachin on the festival and on the seventh year.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא מוֹעֵד, מִשּׁוּם טִירְחָא הוּא, וּבִמְקוֹם פְּסֵידָא שָׁרוּ רַבָּנַן. אֶלָּא שְׁבִיעִית, בֵּין לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִשּׁוּם זוֹרֵעַ וּבֵין לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִשּׁוּם חוֹרֵשׁ, זְרִיעָה וַחֲרִישָׁה בִּשְׁבִיעִית מִי שְׁרֵי?
human_translation: Granted, a Festival, due to exertion in a case of loss, the Sages permitted However, Sabbatical Year, both according to one who said due to sowing, and according to the one who said due to plowing, are sowing and plowing permitted during the Sabbatical Year?
llm_translation: In truth, the festival of Shavuot is due to exertion, and in a place of loss, the Rabbis permitted it. But the seventh year, according to the one who says it is prohibited due to sowing, and according to the one who says it is prohibited due to plowing, is planting and plowing permitted in the seventh year?

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: בִּשְׁבִיעִית בִּזְמַן הַזֶּה, וְרַבִּי הִיא. דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: ״וְזֶה דְּבַר הַשְּׁמִטָּה שָׁמוֹט״. בִּשְׁתֵּי שְׁמִיטוֹת הַכָּתוּב מְדַבֵּר, אַחַת שְׁמִיטַּת קַרְקַע, וְאַחַת שְׁמִיטַּת כְּסָפִים.
human_translation: Abaye said: to the Sabbatical Year in the present time, and it is Rabbi As it is taught Rabbi says: “And this is the manner of the release, will release the verse speaks of two releases: One the release of land, and the other the release of money,
llm_translation: Abaye said: In the seventh year in this time, and it is Rabbi's opinion. As it was taught: Rabbi says, "And this is the matter of the release: release." In two releases the Scripture speaks, one is the release of the land, and one is the release of debts.

hebrew_text: בִּזְמַן שֶׁאַתָּה מְשַׁמֵּט קַרְקַע — אַתָּה מְשַׁמֵּט כְּסָפִים, וּבִזְמַן שֶׁאִי אַתָּה מְשַׁמֵּט קַרְקַע — אִי אַתָּה מְשַׁמֵּט כְּסָפִים.
human_translation: when you release land, you release money, and when you not release land, you need not release money.
llm_translation: In a time when you are releasing land - you are releasing money, and in a time when you are not releasing land - you are not releasing money.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבָּנַן — אָבוֹת אָסַר רַחֲמָנָא,
human_translation: Rava said: Even you say the Rabbis, primary categories of labor were prohibited by the Merciful One,
llm_translation: Rava said: Even if you say it is the opinion of the Rabbis - the Torah forbids.

hebrew_text: תּוֹלָדוֹת לָא אָסַר רַחֲמָנָא. דִּכְתִיב: ״וּבַשָּׁנָה הַשְּׁבִיעִית שַׁבַּת שַׁבָּתוֹן יִהְיֶה לָאָרֶץ שָׂדְךָ לֹא תִזְרָע וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: the subcategories were not prohibited by the Merciful One, as it is written: “But in the seventh year shall be a sabbath of solemn rest for the land, Your field you shall not sow,
llm_translation: The offspring of a non-kosher animal does not render a prohibition by the Merciful One. As it is written: "But in the seventh year, the land shall have a complete rest, a Sabbath to the Lord; you shall not sow your field, etc."

hebrew_text: מִכְּדֵי, זְמִירָה בִּכְלַל זְרִיעָה, וּבְצִירָה בִּכְלַל קְצִירָה. לְמַאי הִלְכְתָא כַּתְבִינְהוּ רַחֲמָנָא?
human_translation: Since pruning is included in sowing, and picking is included in reaping for what halakha did the Merciful One write them?
llm_translation: From that, singing is included in planting, and harvesting is included in reaping. What is the halakha? Let the Merciful One write it for us.

hebrew_text: לְמֵימְרָא דְּאַהָנֵי תּוֹלָדוֹת מִיחַיַּיב, אַאַחְרָנְיָיתָא לָא מִיחַיַּיב.
human_translation: to say for these subcategories is one liable for other one is not liable.
llm_translation: In the matter of one who enjoys the benefits of the produce, he is obligated; in the matter of the final product, he is not obligated.

hebrew_text: וְלָא? וְהָתַנְיָא: ״שָׂדְךָ לֹא תִזְרַע וְכַרְמְךָ לֹא תִזְמוֹר״. אֵין לִי אֶלָּא זֵירוּעַ וְזִימּוּר, מִנַּיִן לְנִיכּוּשׁ וּלְעִידּוּר וּלְכִיסּוּחַ — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״שָׂדְךָ לֹא״, ״כַּרְמְךָ לֹא״. לֹא כׇּל מְלָאכָה שֶׁבְּשָׂדְךָ, וְלֹא כׇּל מְלָאכָה שֶׁבְּכַרְמְךָ.
human_translation: And no Isn’t it taught “Your field you shall not sow, and your vineyard you shall not prune” I have only sowing and pruning. From where weeding, hoeing, and cutting weeds, The verse states: “Your field not “your vineyard not no labor in your field, and no labor in your vineyard.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And not? And it was taught: "Your field you shall not sow, and your vineyard you shall not prune." I have only sowing and pruning, how do I know about uprooting, clearing, and harvesting? The Torah teaches: "Your field not," "your vineyard not." Not every work in your field, and not every work in your vineyard.

hebrew_text: מִנַּיִן שֶׁאֵין מְקַרְסְמִין וְאֵין מְזָרְדִין וְאֵין מְפַסְּגִין בָּאִילָן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״שָׂדְךָ לֹא״, ״כַּרְמְךָ לֹא״. לֹא כׇּל מְלָאכָה שֶׁבְּשָׂדְךָ, וְלֹא כׇּל מְלָאכָה שֶׁבְּכַרְמְךָ.
human_translation: from where one may not prune trees, and one may not trim dry branches and one not cut large branches [ mefasegin ] from trees? The verse states: “Your field not “your vineyard not no labor in your field, and no labor in your vineyard.
llm_translation: From where do we derive that one does not prune, nor hoe, nor harvest on Shabbat? The Torah states: "Your field you shall not," "Your vineyard you shall not." Not every work in your field, and not every work in your vineyard.

hebrew_text: מִנַּיִן שֶׁאֵין מְזַבְּלִין וְאֵין מְפָרְקִין וְאֵין מְאַבְּקִין וְאֵין מְעַשְּׁנִין בָּאִילָן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״שָׂדְךָ לֹא״, ״כַּרְמְךָ לֹא״. כׇּל מְלָאכָה שֶׁבְּשָׂדְךָ לֹא, וְכׇל מְלָאכָה שֶׁבְּכַרְמְךָ לֹא.
human_translation: from where one not fertilize and one may not remove stones and one not dust, and one may not fumigate a tree The verse states: “Your field not “your vineyard not no labor in your field, and no labor in your vineyard.
llm_translation: From where do we derive that one may not fertilize, prune, hoe, or water trees? The Torah states: "Your field shall not," "Your vineyard shall not." Any work that is not done in your field, and any work that is not done in your vineyard.

hebrew_text: יָכוֹל לֹא יְקַשְׁקֵשׁ תַּחַת הַזֵּיתִים, וְלֹא יְעַדֵּר תַּחַת הַגְּפָנִים, וְלֹא יְמַלֵּא נְקָעִים מַיִם, וְלֹא יַעֲשֶׂה עוּגִיּוֹת לַגְּפָנִים — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״שָׂדְךָ לֹא תִזְרָע״.
human_translation: might one may not hoe lightly under olive and one may not hoe under grapevines, and one may not fill cracks with water, and one may not construct circular ditches grapevines the verse states: “Your field you shall not sow.”
llm_translation: He is able not to plow under the olive trees, and not to prune under the grapevines, and not to fill the pits with water, and not to make cakes for the grapevines - as it is taught: "You shall not sow your field."

hebrew_text: זְרִיעָה בַּכְּלָל הָיְתָה, וְלָמָּה יָצְתָה — לְהַקִּישׁ אֵלֶיהָ, לוֹמַר לְךָ: מָה זְרִיעָה מְיוּחֶדֶת עֲבוֹדָה שֶׁבַּשָּׂדֶה וְשֶׁבַּכֶּרֶם, אַף כֹּל שֶׁהִיא עֲבוֹדָה שֶׁבַּשָּׂדֶה וְשֶׁבַּכֶּרֶם!
human_translation: Sowing was included Why was singled out to compare to it say to you: Just as sowing is unique in that it is labor in the field and in the vineyard, so too, any labor in the field and in the vineyard
llm_translation: Sowing was included, and why did it come out - to compare it, to say to you: Just as sowing is a unique service in the field and in the vineyard, so too is any service in the field and in the vineyard!

hebrew_text: מִדְּרַבָּנַן, וּקְרָא אַסְמַכְתָּא בְּעָלְמָא.
human_translation: by rabbinic law, and the verse is a mere support,
llm_translation: From the Rabbis, and a verse is merely a support.

hebrew_text: וְקִשְׁקוּשׁ בִּשְׁבִיעִית מִי שְׁרֵי? וְהָא כְּתִיב: ״וְהַשְּׁבִיעִית תִּשְׁמְטֶנָּה וּנְטַשְׁתָּהּ״ — ״תִּשְׁמְטֶנָּה״ מִלְּקַשְׁקֵשׁ, ״וּנְטַשְׁתָּהּ״ מִלְּסַקֵּל!
human_translation: Is hoeing permitted during the Sabbatical Year? Isn’t it written: “But the seventh year you shall let it rest and lie fallow” “You shall let it rest” from light hoeing, “and lie fallow” from clearing stones.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And is it permitted to engage in commerce during the Sabbatical year? But isn't it written: 'And the seventh year you shall release it, and abandon it' — 'you shall release it' from engaging in commerce, 'and abandon it' from lending!" English translation:

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב עוּקְבָא בַּר חָמָא: תְּרֵי קִשְׁקוּשֵׁי הָווּ. חַד אַבְרוֹיֵי אִילָנֵי, וְחַד סַתּוֹמֵי פִּילֵי. אַבְרוֹיֵי אִילָן — אָסוּר, סַתּוֹמֵי פִּילֵי — שְׁרֵי.
human_translation: Rav Ukva bar Ḥama said: There are two hoeing, one to strengthen trees, and another to seal cracks. to strengthen the tree is prohibited, to seal cracks is permitted,
llm_translation: Rav Ukva bar Ḥama said: Two types of knots there were. One, the knots of tree branches, and one, the knots of elephant ropes. The knots of tree branches are forbidden, the knots of elephant ropes are permitted.

hebrew_text: אִיתְּמַר: הַחוֹרֵשׁ בַּשְּׁבִיעִית, רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן וְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר, חַד אָמַר: לוֹקֶה, וְחַד אָמַר: אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה. לֵימָא בִּדְרַבִּי אָבִין אָמַר רַבִּי אִילְעָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אָבִין אָמַר רַבִּי אִילְעָא: כׇּל מָקוֹם שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר כְּלָל בַּעֲשֵׂה וּפְרָט בְּלֹא תַעֲשֶׂה — אֵין דָּנִין אוֹתוֹ בִּכְלָל וּפְרָט וּכְלָל.
human_translation: It was stated Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar one who plows during the Sabbatical Year. One said: He is flogged while the one said: He is not flogged. Let us say that they disagree with regard to Rabbi Avin Rabbi Ile’a said, As, Rabbi Avin said Rabbi Ile’a said: Wherever a generalization is stated as a positive and a detail as a negative one does not apply a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization,
llm_translation: It was stated: One who plows on the seventh year, Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Elazar, one said: he is liable to punishment, and one said: he is not liable to punishment. Let us say that Rabbi Avin said that Rabbi Ilai argued. For Rabbi Avin said that Rabbi Ilai said: Any place where it is stated a general principle in the positive and a specific detail in the negative - one does not include it in the general principle, the specific detail, and the general principle.

hebrew_text: מַאן דְּאָמַר לוֹקֶה — לֵית לֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי אָבִין אָמַר רַבִּי אִילְעָא.
human_translation: The one who said is flogged does not that Rabbi Avin Rabbi Ile’a said.
llm_translation: The one who says "he is liable" - there is no one who agrees with Rabbi Avin; Rabbi Ile'a said.

hebrew_text: וּמַאן דְּאָמַר אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה — אִית לֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי אָבִין.
human_translation: And the one who said one is not flogged holds that Rabbi Avin
llm_translation: And one who says he is not liable - he has the opinion of Rabbi Avin.

hebrew_text: לָא, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לֵית לֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי אָבִין אָמַר רַבִּי אִילְעָא, מַאן דְּאָמַר לוֹקֶה — שַׁפִּיר.
human_translation: No, everyone is not that Rabbi Avin Rabbi Ile’a said. the one who said he is flogged, well,
llm_translation: Not, all the world has not Rabbi Avin said Rabbi Ilai, who says lashes - good.

hebrew_text: וּמַאן דְּאָמַר אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה, אָמַר לָךְ: מִכְּדִי זְמִירָה בִּכְלַל זְרִיעָה וּבְצִירָה בִּכְלַל קְצִירָה, לְמַאי הִלְכְתָא כַּתְבִינְהוּ רַחֲמָנָא? לְמֵימַר דְּאַהָנֵי תּוֹלָדוֹת הוּא דְּמִיחַיַּיב, אַתּוֹלָדָה אַחֲרִינָא לָא מִיחַיַּיב.
human_translation: And the one who said he is not flogged said to you: Since pruning is in sowing, and picking is of reaping, for what halakha did the Merciful One write them? to say for these subcategories is one liable for other subcategories one is not liable.
llm_translation: And one who says he is not liable, he says to you: Since singing is included in planting, and harvesting is included in reaping, what is the halacha that the Merciful One wrote? To say that it is the offspring that is liable, but another offspring is not liable.

hebrew_text: וְלָא? וְהָתַנְיָא: ״שָׂדְךָ לֹא תִזְרַע וְכַרְמְךָ לֹא תִזְמוֹר״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא זֵירוּעַ וְזִימּוּר. מִנְיָן לְעִידּוּר וּלְקִישְׁקוּשׁ וּלְכִיסּוּחַ? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״שָׂדְךָ לֹא״, ״כַּרְמְךָ לֹא״. לֹא כׇּל מְלָאכָה שֶׁבְּשָׂדְךָ וְלֹא כׇּל מְלָאכָה שֶׁבְּכַרְמְךָ.
human_translation: And no Isn’t it taught “Your field you shall not sow, and your vineyard you shall not prune” I have only sowing and pruning? From where weeding, hoeing, and cutting weeds The verse states: “Your field not your vineyard not not any labor that in your field, and not any labor that in your vineyard.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And not? And it was taught: "Your field you shall not sow, and your vineyard you shall not prune." I have only learned about sowing and pruning. From where do we learn about hoeing, weeding, and watering? The Talmud teaches: "Your field you shall not," "your vineyard you shall not." Not every task in your field and not every task in your vineyard.

hebrew_text: וּמִנַּיִן שֶׁאֵין מְקַרְסְמִין, וְאֵין מְזָרְדִין, וְאֵין מְפַסְּגִין בָּאִילָן תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״שָׂדְךָ לֹא״, ״כַּרְמְךָ לֹא״: כׇּל מְלָאכָה שֶׁבְּשָׂדְךָ לֹא כׇּל מְלָאכָה שֶׁבְּכַרְמְךָ לֹא.
human_translation: from where one may not prune trees, and one may not trim dry branches and one not cut large branches from trees? The verse states: “Your field not your vineyard not any labor in your field may not and any labor in your vineyard may not
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And from where do we derive that one may not prune, and may not hoe, and may not harvest from a tree? The Talmud teaches: "Your field - not," "Your vineyard - not": all labor that is in your field - not, all labor that is in your vineyard - not.

hebrew_text: מִנַּיִן שֶׁאֵין מְזַבְּלִין וְאֵין מְפָרְקִין וְאֵין מְעַשְּׁנִין בָּאִילָן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״שָׂדְךָ לֹא״, ״כַּרְמְךָ לֹא״. כׇּל מְלָאכָה שֶׁבְּשָׂדְךָ לֹא, וְכׇל מְלָאכָה שֶׁבְּכַרְמְךָ לֹא.
human_translation: From where one may not fertilize and one may not remove stones and one may not fumigate a tree The verse states: “Your field not your vineyard not any labor in your field may not and any labor in your vineyard may not
llm_translation: From where do we derive that one may not fertilize, prune, or graft onto a tree? The Talmud teaches: "Your field shall not," "Your vineyard shall not." Any work that is not done in your field, and any work that is not done in your vineyard.

hebrew_text: יָכוֹל לֹא יְקַשְׁקֵשׁ תַּחַת הַזֵּיתִים, וְלֹא יְעַדֵּר תַּחַת הַגְּפָנִים, וְלֹא יְמַלֵּא נְקָעִים מַיִם, וְלֹא יַעֲשֶׂה עוּגִיּוֹת לַגְּפָנִים — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״שָׂדְךָ לֹא תִזְרָע״.
human_translation: might one may not hoe under olive and one may not hoe under grapevines, and one may not fill cracks with water, and one may not construct circular ditches grapevines the verse states: “Your field you shall not sow.”
llm_translation: He is able not to plow under the olive trees, and not to prune under the grapevines, and not to fill the pits with water, and not to make cakes for the grapevines - as it is taught: "You shall not sow your field."

hebrew_text: זְרִיעָה בַּכְּלָל הָיְתָה, וְלָמָּה יָצְתָה — לְהַקִּישׁ אֵלֶיהָ, לוֹמַר לָךְ: מָה זְרִיעָה מְיוּחֶדֶת עֲבוֹדָה שֶׁבַּשָּׂדֶה וְשֶׁבַּכֶּרֶם, אַף כֹּל שֶׁהִיא עֲבוֹדָה שֶׁבַּשָּׂדֶה וְשֶׁבַּכֶּרֶם!
human_translation: Sowing was included Why was singled out to compare to say to you: Just as sowing is unique in that it is labor in the field and in the vineyard, so too, any other labor in the field and in the vineyard
llm_translation: Sowing was included, and why was it mentioned? To compare it, to say to you: Just as sowing is a specialized labor in the field and in the vineyard, so too, any labor that is in the field and in the vineyard!

hebrew_text: מִדְּרַבָּנַן, וּקְרָא אַסְמַכְתָּא בְּעָלְמָא.
human_translation: by rabbinic law, and the verse is a mere support,
llm_translation: From the Rabbis, and a verse is merely a support.

hebrew_text: כִּי אֲתָא רַב דִּימִי, אָמַר: יָכוֹל יִלְקֶה עַל הַתּוֹסֶפֶת. וְנָסֵיב לַהּ תַּלְמוּדָא לִפְטוּרָא, וְלָא יָדַעְנָא מַאי תַּלְמוּדָא וּמַאי תּוֹסֶפֶת.
human_translation: When Rav Dimi came he stated might that one would be flogged for the addition, but a teaching states an exemption But I do not know what teaching or what addition
llm_translation: When Rav Dimi came, he said: Can one be liable for an addition? And he married her to exempt her, and we did not know what is the Talmuda and what is the Tosfeta.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר אָמַר: חֲרִישָׁה. וְהָכִי קָאָמַר: יָכוֹל יִלְקֶה עַל חֲרִישָׁה דְּאָתְיָא מִכְּלָל וּפְרָט וּכְלָל, וְנָסֵיב לֵיהּ תַּלְמוּדָא לִפְטוּרָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar said: plowing And this is what it is saying: might one would be flogged for plowing as it is derived by way a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization But a teaching states an exemption
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar said: silence. And thus he said: one might think that one is liable for silence that comes from a generalization, specification, and generalization, and the Talmud comes and exempts him.

hebrew_text: דְּאִם כֵּן, כׇּל הָנֵי פְּרָטֵי לְמָה לִי?
human_translation: because if why do I all these details
llm_translation: "If so, why do I need all these details?"

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: יָמִים שֶׁהוֹסִיפוּ חֲכָמִים לִפְנֵי רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה. וְהָכִי קָאָמַר: יָכוֹל יִלְקֶה עַל תּוֹסֶפֶת רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה, דְּאָתְיָא ״מִבֶּחָרִישׁ וּבַקָּצִיר תִּשְׁבֹּת״, וְנָסֵיב לַהּ תַּלְמוּדָא לִפְטוּרָא, כִּדְבָעֵינַן לְמֵימַר לְקַמַּן.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: the days that the Sages added before Rosh HaShana And this is what it is saying: might one would be flogged for the additional Rosh HaShana as is derived “In plowing and in reaping you shall rest” But a teaching states an exemption as we are about to state below.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: Days that the sages added before Rosh Hashanah. And thus he said: One might think that one could be lashed for the addition of Rosh Hashanah, as it is written, "You shall cease from plowing and harvesting." And he brought a proof from the Talmud to exempt it, as we will say later.

hebrew_text: מַאי יָמִים שֶׁלִּפְנֵי רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה, כְּדִתְנַן: עַד מָתַי חוֹרְשִׁין בִּשְׂדֵה אִילָן עֶרֶב שְׁבִיעִית? בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: כׇּל זְמַן שֶׁיָּפֶה לַפְּרִי — וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: עַד הָעֲצֶרֶת. וּקְרוֹבִין דִּבְרֵי אֵלּוּ לִהְיוֹת כְּדִבְרֵי אֵלּוּ.
human_translation: What days before Rosh HaShana? As we learned Until when may plow an orchard the eve of the Sabbatical Year? Beit Shammai say: so long as is beneficial for the fruit And Beit Hillel say: until Shavuot . And the statement of these, is close to being like the statement of these,
llm_translation: What are the days before Rosh Hashanah? As we have learned: Until when may one plow in the field of a tree in the evening of the seventh year? Beit Shammai says: As long as it is beneficial for the fruit to ripen. Beit Hillel says: Until Sukkot. And the opinions of these are close to being like the opinions of those.

hebrew_text: וְעַד מָתַי חוֹרְשִׁין שְׂדֵה הַלָּבָן עֶרֶב שְׁבִיעִית? מִשֶּׁתִּכְלֶה הַלֵּחָה, וְכׇל זְמַן שֶׁבְּנֵי אָדָם חוֹרְשִׁים לִיטַּע מִקְשָׁאוֹת וּמִדְלָעוֹת.
human_translation: And until when may plow a white field, the eve of the Sabbatical Year? until the moisture ceases and so long as people plow to plant cucumbers and gourds,
llm_translation: And until when do they plow the field of white (cotton) in the eve of the seventh (year)? From when the plowing is completed, and as long as people plow to plant flax and sesame.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: אִם כֵּן נָתְנָה תּוֹרָה שִׁיעוּר לְכׇל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד בְּיָדוֹ. אֶלָּא: בִּשְׂדֵה הַלָּבָן — עַד הַפֶּסַח, וּבִשְׂדֵה הָאִילָן — עַד הָעֲצֶרֶת. וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: עַד הַפֶּסַח.
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: If it is so the Torah has given an measure into the hands of each and every individual. Rather, In a white field until Passover, in an orchard until Shavuot , and Beit Hillel say: Until Passover.
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: If so, the Torah gave a measure to each and every one in his hand. Rather, in a field of white grain—until Passover, and in a field of trees—until Shavuot. And Beit Hillel says: Until Passover.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי מִשּׁוּם בַּר קַפָּרָא: רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל וּבֵית דִּינוֹ נִמְנוּ עַל שְׁנֵי פְּרָקִים הַלָּלוּ, וּבִטְּלוּם.
human_translation: And Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said in the name of bar Kappara: Rabban Gamliel and his court voted about the these two periods, and nullified them,
llm_translation: And Rabbi Shimon ben Pazzi said in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi in the name of Bar Kappara: Rabban Gamliel and his court were counted as two chapters of these Hallel, and they annulled them.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי זֵירָא לְרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ לְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל וּבֵית דִּינוֹ הֵיכִי מָצוּ מְבַטְּלִי תַּקַּנְתָּא דְּבֵית שַׁמַּאי וּבֵית הִלֵּל? וְהָא תְּנַן: אֵין בֵּית דִּין יָכוֹל לְבַטֵּל דִּבְרֵי בֵּית דִּין חֲבֵירוֹ אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן גָּדוֹל מִמֶּנּוּ בְּחָכְמָה וּבְמִנְיָן!
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Abbahu, and some say Reish Lakish to Rabbi Yoḥanan: How could Rabban Gamliel and his court nullify an ordinance Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, Didn’t we learn A court cannot nullify the ruling of another unless it surpasses it in wisdom and in number?
llm_translation: He said to him, Rabbi Zeira to Rabbi Avahu, and some say Reish Lakish to Rabbi Yochanan: How did Rabban Gamliel and his court find a way to annul the enactment of Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel? But didn't we learn: A court cannot annul the words of another court unless it is greater than it in wisdom and number!

hebrew_text: ״אֶשְׁתּוֹמַם כְּשָׁעָה חֲדָא״. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אֵימוֹר, כָּךְ הִתְנוּ בֵּינֵיהֶן: כָּל הָרוֹצֶה לְבַטֵּל — יָבוֹא וִיבַטֵּל.
human_translation: “was astonished for a while” said to him: Say they stipulated among themselves: Anyone who wishes to nullify may come and nullify
llm_translation: "Estomam k'sha'ah chada." Amar lei: eimor, kach hitnu beineihen: kol harotzeh levatel - yavo viyvatel.

hebrew_text: דִּידְהוּ הִיא? הֲלָכָה לְמֹשֶׁה מִסִּינַי הִיא! דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אַסִּי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי נְחוּנְיָא אִישׁ בִּקְעַת בֵּית חוֹרְתָן: עֶשֶׂר נְטִיעוֹת, עֲרָבָה, וְנִיסּוּךְ הַמַּיִם, הֲלָכָה לְמֹשֶׁה מִסִּינַי!
human_translation: Is this theirs? It is a halakha to Moses from Sinai. As Rabbi Asi said Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Neḥunya from the valley of Beit Ḥortan: ten saplings, willow water libation halakhot to Moses from Sinai.
llm_translation: It is their opinion? It is a halakha law to Moses from Sinai! As Rabbi Assi said in the name of Rabbi Yohanan in the name of Rabbi Neḥunia the man of the valley of Beit Ḥorṭan: Ten saplings, a furrow, and the pouring of water, it is a halakha to Moses from Sinai!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: כִּי גְּמִירִי הִלְכְתָא, שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם לִפְנֵי רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה, וַאֲתוֹ הָנֵי תַּקּוּן מִפֶּסַח וּמֵעֲצֶרֶת, וְאַתְנוֹ בְּדִידְהוּ: כָּל הָרוֹצֶה לְבַטֵּל יָבוֹא וִיבַטֵּל.
human_translation: Rabbi Yitzḥak said: When they learned halakha thirty days before Rosh HaShana. these came instituted from Passover and from Shavuot , but they stipulated among themselves: Anyone who wishes to nullify may come and nullify
llm_translation: Rabbi Yitzchak said: When the Halacha is concluded, thirty days before Rosh Hashanah, and these enactments came from Pesach and Shavuot, and they came on their own: anyone who wishes to annul may come and annul.

hebrew_text: וְהָנֵי הִלְכְתָא נִינְהוּ? קְרָאֵי נִינְהוּ, דִּתְנַן: ״בֶּחָרִישׁ וּבַקָּצִיר תִּשְׁבֹּת״, רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: אֵין צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר חָרִישׁ וְקָצִיר שֶׁל שְׁבִיעִית, שֶׁהֲרֵי כְּבָר נֶאֱמַר: ״שָׂדְךָ לֹא תִזְרָע וְכַרְמְךָ לֹא תִזְמֹר״, אֶלָּא חָרִישׁ שֶׁל עֶרֶב שְׁבִיעִית
human_translation: Are these halakhot They are verses. As we learned “In plowing and in reaping you shall rest” Rabbi Akiva says: It is unnecessary to speak plowing and reaping during the Sabbatical Year, as it was already stated: your field you shall not sow, and your vineyard you shall not prune” Rather, plowing on the eve of the Sabbatical Year
llm_translation: The matter at hand, what are they? They are verses, as we learned: "You shall cease in plowing time and in harvest time." Rabbi Akiva says: There is no need to mention plowing and harvesting of the seventh year, for it is already stated: "You shall not sow your field or prune your vineyard." Rather, it refers to the plowing of the eve of the seventh year.

hebrew_text: שֶׁנִּכְנָס לִשְׁבִיעִית, וְקָצִיר שֶׁל שְׁבִיעִית שֶׁיָּצָא לְמוֹצָאֵי שְׁבִיעִית.
human_translation: that entered into the Sabbatical Year, and reaping of the Sabbatical Year that continued into the conclusion of the Sabbatical Year,
llm_translation: When one enters the seventh year, and the harvest of the seventh year that goes out to the end of the seventh year.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אוֹמֵר: מָה חָרִישׁ רְשׁוּת, אַף קָצִיר — רְשׁוּת, יָצָא קְצִיר הָעוֹמֶר שֶׁהִיא מִצְוָה!
human_translation: Rabbi Yishmael says Just as optional plowing so too, optional reaping to the exclusion of the reaping of the omer which is a mitzva,
llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael says: Just as silence is optional, so too harvesting is optional. The harvesting of the Omer offering, which is a commandment, exempts other harvesting.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: כִּי גְּמִירִי הִלְכְתָא — לְמִישְׁרֵי יַלְדָּה. קְרָאֵי — לְמֵיסַר זְקֵינָה.
human_translation: Rather, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: When we learned a halakha it was to permit young the verses to prohibit mature
llm_translation: Rather, said Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak: When one learns a law - for the sake of the straightness of the child. Verses - for the sake of honoring the elderly.

hebrew_text: וְכֵיוָן דְּהִלְכְתָא לְמִשְׁרֵי יַלְדָּה, לָאו מִמֵּילָא זְקֵינָה אֲסִירָה?!
human_translation: But since the halakha to permit young does it not automatically mature is prohibited
llm_translation: And since the path to the bed of a young woman is not like that of an old woman, is she not forbidden?!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: הִלְכְתָא לְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, קְרָאֵי לְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא.
human_translation: Rather, halakha according to Rabbi Yishmael, the verses according to the Rabbi Akiva.
llm_translation: Rather: the halakha is according to Rabbi Yishmael, the verses are according to Rabbi Akiva.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל וּבֵית דִּינוֹ מִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא בַּטֻּל לְהוּ.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yoḥanan said Rabban Gamliel and his court nullified based on in the Torah.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: Rabban Gamliel and his court are nullified from the Torah.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא? גָּמַר ״שַׁבָּת״ ״שַׁבָּת״ מִשַּׁבַּת בְּרֵאשִׁית. מָה לְהַלָּן — הִיא אֲסוּרָה לְפָנֶיהָ וּלְאַחֲרֶיהָ מוּתָּרִין, אַף כָּאן — הִיא אֲסוּרָה לְפָנֶיהָ וּלְאַחֲרֶיהָ מוּתָּרִין.
human_translation: What is the reason? He derives Shabbat and Shabbat the Shabbat of Creation. Just as there, itself it is prohibited before and after it is permitted, so too here, itself it is prohibited before and after it is permitted.
llm_translation: What is the reason? He concluded "Shabbat," "Shabbat" from "Shabbat" in Genesis. Just as there — it is forbidden before it and after it, but permitted, so too here — it is forbidden before it and after it, but permitted.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב אָשֵׁי: מַאן דְּאָמַר הִלְכְתָא — אָתְיָא גְּזֵרָה שָׁוָה עָקְרָה הִלְכְתָא? וּמַאן דְּאָמַר קְרָא — אָתְיָא גְּזֵרָה שָׁוָה עָקְרָה קְרָא?
human_translation: Rav Ashi strongly objects to this: the one who said halakha can a verbal analogy come uproot a halakha And the one who said a verse, can a verbal analogy come uproot a verse?
llm_translation: Challenges to him Rav Ashi: Who said Halakha - comes a decree similar uproots Halakha? And who said Scripture - comes a decree similar uproots Scripture?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל וּבֵית דִּינוֹ סָבְרִי לַהּ כְּרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, דְּאָמַר הִלְכְתָא גְּמִירִי לַהּ. וְכִי גְּמִירִי הִלְכְתָא, בִּזְמַן שֶׁבֵּית הַמִּקְדָּשׁ קַיָּים — דּוּמְיָא דְּנִיסּוּךְ הַמַּיִם. אֲבָל בִּזְמַן שֶׁאֵין בֵּית הַמִּקְדָּשׁ קַיָּים — לָא.
human_translation: Rather, Rav Ashi said: Rabban Gamliel and his court held in accordance with Rabbi Yishmael, who said they learned this a halakha But they learned this halakha when the Temple is standing. similar to water libation, But when the Temple is not standing does not
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Ashi said: Rabban Gamliel and his court hold like Rabbi Yishmael, who said the halacha is in accordance with their opinion. And when is the halacha in accordance with their opinion? When the Temple is standing, resembling the pouring of water. But when the Temple is not standing, it is not so.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל לֹא מִמֵּי הַגְּשָׁמִים וּמִמֵּי הַקִּילוֹן. בִּשְׁלָמָא מֵי קִילוֹן — אִיכָּא טִירְחָא יַתִּירָא, אֶלָּא מֵי גְּשָׁמִים מַאי טִירְחָא אִיכָּא?
human_translation: However, may not with rainwater or with water drawn with a shadoof. Granted, water drawn with a shadoof involves excessive effort, But what excessive effort is involved with rainwater?
llm_translation: But not from rainwater and not from water of a cistern. Granted, water of a cistern - there is an extra exertion, but rainwater, what extra exertion is there?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אִילְעָא אָמַר יוֹחָנָן: גְּזֵירָה מֵי גְשָׁמִים אַטּוּ מֵי קִילוֹן. רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: מֵי גְשָׁמִים גּוּפַיְיהוּ לִידֵי מֵי קִילוֹן אָתוּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Ile’a said that Yoḥanan said: decree rainwater due to to water drawn with a shadoof. Rav Ashi said: Rainwater itself will come to be water drawn with a shadoof.
llm_translation: Rabbi Ilai said in the name of Yochanan: A decree from rainwater, but not from water of a cistern. Rav Ashi said: Rainwater itself leads to water of a cistern.

hebrew_text: וְקָמִיפַּלְגִי בִּדְרַבִּי זֵירָא. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר יִרְמְיָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: נְהָרוֹת הַמּוֹשְׁכִין מַיִם מִן הָאֲגַמִּים מוּתָּר לְהַשְׁקוֹת מֵהֶן בְּחוּלּוֹ שֶׁל מוֹעֵד.
human_translation: disagree with regard to Rabbi Zeira, as Rabbi Zeira said Rabba bar Yirmeya said Shmuel said: streams that draw water from pools one is permitted to irrigate from them on the intermediate days of a Festival,
llm_translation: And there arose a disagreement between Rabbi Zeira, for Rabbi Zeira said in the name of Rabba bar Yirmeya who said in the name of Shmuel: "It is permitted to drink water from flowing rivers that come from lakes on the festival day."

hebrew_text: מָר אִית לֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי זֵירָא, וּמָר לֵית לֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי זֵירָא.
human_translation: Sage, is of of Rabbi Zeira, And Sage, is not of Rabbi Zeira,
llm_translation: Master has a son of Rabbi Zeira, and master does not have a son of Rabbi Zeira.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא, אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר יִרְמְיָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: נְהָרוֹת הַמּוֹשְׁכִין מַיִם מִן הָאֲגַמִּים — מוּתָּר לְהַשְׁקוֹת מֵהֶן בְּחוּלּוֹ שֶׁל מוֹעֵד.
human_translation: the itself. Rabbi Zeira said Rabba bar Yirmeya said Shmuel said: streams that draw water from pools one is permitted to irrigate from them on the intermediate days of a Festival.
llm_translation: The body, said Rabbi Zeira said Rabba bar Yirmeya said Shmuel: Rivers that flow water from the lakes - it is permitted to water from them in the weekday of the festival.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה לְרַבִּי זֵירָא: אֲבָל לֹא מִמֵּי גְשָׁמִים וְלֹא מִמֵּי קִילוֹן! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: יִרְמְיָה בְּרִי, הָנֵי אַגַּמִּים דְּבָבֶל — כְּמַיָּא דְּלָא פָּסְקִי דָּמוּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya raised an objection to Rabbi Zeira However, one may not with rainwater or with water drawn with a shadoof. said to him: Yirmeya, my son, these pools in Babylonia are like water that does not stop
llm_translation: He raised an objection to him, Rabbi Yirmeya to Rabbi Zeira: But not from rainwater, and not from Kil'on water! He said to him: Yirmeya my son, those marshes of Babylon are like water that does not cease flowing.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הַפְּסִיקוֹת וְהַבְּרֵיכוֹת שֶׁנִּתְמַלְּאוּ מַיִם מֵעֶרֶב יוֹם טוֹב — אָסוּר לְהַשְׁקוֹת מֵהֶן בְּחוּלּוֹ שֶׁל מוֹעֵד. וְאִם הָיְתָה אַמַּת הַמַּיִם עוֹבֶרֶת בֵּינֵיהֶן — מוּתָּר.
human_translation: The Sages taught temporary pools and pools that were filled with water on the eve of a Festival, it is prohibited for one to irrigate from them on the intermediate days of the Festival, But if a water channel passes between them it is permitted.
llm_translation: The sages taught: Cisterns and pools that filled with water on Erev Yom Tov - it is forbidden to draw water from them on Chol HaMoed. And if a stream of water passes between them - it is permitted.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: וְהוּא שֶׁרוּבָּהּ שֶׁל אוֹתָהּ שָׂדֶה שׁוֹתָה מֵאוֹתָהּ אַמַּת הַמַּיִם. רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין רוּבָּהּ שֶׁל אוֹתָהּ שָׂדֶה שׁוֹתָה, כֵּיוָן דְּקָא מָשְׁכָא וְאָתְיָא, מֵימָר אָמַר: אִי לָא שָׁתְיָא לְחַד יוֹמָא — תִּשְׁתֵּי לִתְרֵי וּתְלָתָא יוֹמֵי.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: And this when the majority of that field can be irrigated from that water channel, Rav Ashi said: even though the majority of that field cannot be irrigated Since continuously draws say if cannot be irrigated on a single day, it can be irrigated over two or three days.
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: And that which the majority of that field drinks from that cubit of water. Rav Ashe said: Even though the majority of that field does not drink, since it is being drawn and coming, the statement says: If it did not drink for one day — it will drink for two or three days.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: בְּרֵיכָה שֶׁנּוֹטֶפֶת מַיִם מִשְּׂדֵה בֵּית הַשְּׁלָחִין זוֹ — מוּתָּר לְהַשְׁקוֹת מִמֶּנָּה שְׂדֵה בֵּית הַשְּׁלָחִין אַחֶרֶת.
human_translation: The Sages taught a pool drips water from this field that requires irrigation, one is permitted to irrigate from another field that requires irrigation.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: A cistern from which water drips from the field of the privy, this one - it is permitted to water another field of the privy from it.

hebrew_text: וְהָא עֲבִידָא דְּפָסְקָא! אָמַר רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה: וַעֲדַיִין הִיא מְטַפְטֶפֶת. אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: וְהוּא שֶׁלֹּא פָּסַק מַעְיָין רִאשׁוֹן.
human_translation: But isn’t likely to stop flowing, Rabbi Yirmeya said: is still trickling Abaye said: And this when the first spring has not stopped
llm_translation: The matter of the conclusion! Rabbi Yirmiyah said: And yet it is still dripping. Abaye said: And that is because it did not stop the first source of the spring.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן מְנַסְיָא אוֹמֵר: שְׁתֵּי עֲרוּגוֹת זוֹ לְמַעְלָה מִזּוֹ — לֹא יִדְלֶה מִן הַתַּחְתּוֹנָה וְיַשְׁקֶה אֶת הָעֶלְיוֹנָה. יוֹתֵר עַל כֵּן אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בַּר שִׁמְעוֹן: אֲפִילּוּ עֲרוּגָה אַחַת חֶצְיָהּ נָמוּךְ וְחֶצְיָהּ גָּבוֹהַּ — לֹא יִדְלֶה מִמָּקוֹם נָמוּךְ וְיַשְׁקֶה לְמָקוֹם גָּבוֹהַּ.
human_translation: It is taught Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya says: two garden beds one above the other, one may not draw from the lower to irrigate the upper Furthermore, Rabbi Elazar bar Shimon said: Even a single garden bed, half of which is lower and half of which is higher, one may not draw from the the lower area to irrigate the upper area,
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya says: Two bundles, one above the other - one should not remove from the lower one and water the upper one. Furthermore, Rabbi Elazar bar Shimon said: Even if one bundle is half low and half high - one should not remove from the low part and water the high part.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מַדְלִין לִירָקוֹת כְּדֵי לְאוֹכְלָן, וְאִם בִּשְׁבִיל לְיַיפּוֹתָן — אָסוּר.
human_translation: The Sages taught One may draw vegetables in order to eat them But if in order to enhance their it is prohibited,
llm_translation: The sages taught: One may salt vegetables in order to eat them, but if it is for their preservation, it is prohibited.

hebrew_text: רָבִינָא וְרַבָּה תּוֹסְפָאָה הֲווֹ קָא אָזְלִי בְּאוֹרְחָא. חֲזוֹ לְהָהוּא גַּבְרָא דַּהֲוָה דָּלֵי דַּוְולָא בְּחוּלָּא דְּמוֹעֲדָא, אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבָּה תּוֹסְפָאָה לְרָבִינָא: לֵיתֵי מָר לְשַׁמְּתֵיהּ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: וְהָתַנְיָא: מַדְלִין לִירָקוֹת כְּדֵי לְאוֹכְלָן. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִי סָבְרַתְּ מַאי ״מַדְלִין״ — מַדְלִין מַיָּא? מַאי
human_translation: Ravina and Rabba Tosefa’a were walking along the road they saw a certain man that was drawing with a bucket on the intermediate days of a Festival. Rabba Tosefa’a said to Ravina: Let the Master come and excommunicate him said to him: But isn’t it taught One may draw for vegetables in order to eat them, said to him: Do you maintain what is one may draw madlin is one may draw water what is
llm_translation: Ravina and Rabba Tosfa'ah were walking on the road. They saw a certain man who was poor and was gathering vegetables in the field of the festival. Rabba Tosfa'ah said to Ravina: "Let the Master come to his aid." He said to him: "But isn't it taught: One may gather vegetables in order to eat them?" He said to him: "Do you think 'gather' means gathering water? What is..."

hebrew_text: ״מַדְלִין״ — שַׁלּוֹפֵי. כְּדִתְנַן: הַמֵּידֵל בַּגְּפָנִים, כְּשֵׁם שֶׁהוּא מֵידֵל בְּשֶׁלּוֹ — כָּךְ הוּא מֵידֵל בְּשֶׁל עֲנִיִּים, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: בְּשֶׁלּוֹ רַשַּׁאי, וְאֵינוֹ רַשַּׁאי בְּשֶׁל עֲנִיִּים.
human_translation: one may draw one may pull out As we learned One who thins out [ meidel ] the vines just as he may thin out his own so too, he may thin out the poor. the statemen of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Meir says: His own he is permitted but he is not permitted for the poor.
llm_translation: "Madlin" - pruning. As it was taught: One who prunes in a vineyard, just as he prunes in his own vineyard, so too he prunes in the vineyard of the poor - the words of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Meir says: He is permitted to prune his own, but not permitted to prune that of the poor.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ, וְהָתַנְיָא: מַדְלִין מַיִם לִירָקוֹת כְּדֵי לְאוֹכְלָן! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִי תַּנְיָא — תַּנְיָא.
human_translation: said to But wasn’t it taught One may draw water vegetables in order to eat them? said to him: If it is taught it is taught,
llm_translation: He said to him, and it was taught: One may pour water for vegetables in order to eat them! He said to him: If it was taught - it was taught.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין עוֹשִׂין עוּגִיּוֹת לַגְּפָנִים. מַאי עוּגִיּוֹת? אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה: בַּנְכֵּי. תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: אֵלּוּ הֵן עוּגִיּוֹת — בְּדִידִין שֶׁבְּעִיקָּרֵי זֵיתִים וְשֶׁבְּעִיקָּרֵי גְפָנִים.
human_translation: And one may not construct circular ditches [ ugiyyot ] grapevines What are ugiyyot ? Rav Yehuda said: binkei , this is also taught These are ugiyyot : Bedidin , around the bases of olive trees and around the bases of grapevines.
llm_translation: And they do not make cakes for the vineyards. What are "cakes"? Rav Yehudah said: fig cakes. It was also taught likewise: These are the cakes - made of the kernels of olives and the kernels of grapes.

hebrew_text: אִינִי? וְהָא רַב יְהוּדָה שְׁרָא לִבְנֵי בַּר צֵיתַאי לְמֶעְבַּד בַּנְכֵּי לְכַרְמֵיהוֹן! לָא קַשְׁיָא הָא בְּחַדְתֵי, הָא בְּעַתִּיקֵי.
human_translation: Is that so? Didn’t Rav Yehuda permit the family of bar Tzitai to construct circular ditches for their vineyards not difficult. This new That old
llm_translation: I am not? But didn't Rav Yehudah permit the sons of Bar Tzitta to work with young vines in their vineyard! It is not difficult - this one is in the case of new vines, and that one is in the case of old vines.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה אוֹמֵר: אֵין עוֹשִׂין אֶת הָאַמָּה. בִּשְׁלָמָא מוֹעֵד — מִשּׁוּם דְּקָא טָרַח, אֶלָּא שְׁבִיעִית מַאי טַעְמָא?
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says: One may not construct a new channel Granted, a Festival, because he exerts himself But what is the reason the Sabbatical Year,
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah says: One does not make the cubit. Regarding the festival it is understandable - because he is exerting effort, but what is the reason for the seventh year?

hebrew_text: פְּלִיגוּ בַּהּ רַבִּי זֵירָא וְרַבִּי אַבָּא בַּר מֶמֶל. חַד אָמַר: מִפְּנֵי שֶׁנִּרְאֶה כְּעוֹדֵר. וְחַד אָמַר: מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמַּכְשִׁיר אֲגַפֶּיהָ לִזְרִיעָה.
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira and Rabbi Abba bar Memel disagreed with regard to this One said: because it appears as if he were hoeing And one said: because he prepares banks for planting,
llm_translation: They disputed it: Rabbi Zeira and Rabbi Abba bar Memel. One said: Because it appears like a flock. And one said: Because it prepares its wings for sowing.

hebrew_text: מַאי בֵּינַיְיהוּ? אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ דְּקָא אָתוּ מַיָּא בָּתְרֵיהּ. מַאן דְּאָמַר מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמַּכְשִׁיר אֲגַפֶּיהָ לִזְרִיעָה — אִיכָּא, וּמַאן דְּאָמַר מִפְּנֵי שֶׁנִּרְאֶה כְּעוֹדֵר — לֵיכָּא.
human_translation: What is between them? There is between them water comes after he the one who said because he prepares its banks for planting, there is But the one who said because it appears as if he were hoeing, there is no
llm_translation: What is the difference between them? There is a difference between them in that they come after the water. One who says that it is permissible due to preparing it for planting - there is, and one who says that it appears as a flock - there is not.

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִפְּנֵי שֶׁנִּרְאֶה כְּעוֹדֵר, לֵיחוּשׁ מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמַּכְשִׁיר אֲגַפֶּיהָ לִזְרִיעָה? אֶלָּא, אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ דְּקָא שָׁקֵיל מִינֵּיהּ וְשָׁדֵי לְבָרַאי. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמַּכְשִׁיר אֲגַפֶּיהָ לִזְרִיעָה — לֵיכָּא. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִפְּנֵי שֶׁנִּרְאֶה כְּעוֹדֵר — אִיכָּא.
human_translation: But according to the one who said because it appears as if he were hoeing, let him be concerned that prepares banks for planting Rather, there is between them where he takes from and throws outside. According to the one who said because he prepares banks for planting, there is no according to the one who said because it appears as if he were hoeing, there is
llm_translation: And for the one who says because it appears like a flock, should we be concerned that it may be fit for planting? Rather, there is a distinction between them, as one takes from it and leaves for the Creator. For the one who says because it may be fit for planting - there is no concern. For the one who says because it appears like a flock - there is a distinction.

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמַּכְשִׁיר אֲגַפֶּיהָ לִזְרִיעָה, לֵיחוּשׁ מִפְּנֵי שֶׁנִּרְאֶה כְּעוֹדֵר! עוֹדֵר נָמֵי, כִּי קָא שָׁקֵיל, בְּדוּכְתֵּיהּ מַנַּח לֵיהּ.
human_translation: But according to the one who said because he prepares its banks for planting, let him be concerned that appears as if he were hoeing. also one who hoes when he takes puts it down in its place.
llm_translation: And for the one who says, because it makes its edges fit for planting, should he be concerned because it appears like a furrow? A furrow is different, for it is being leveled, he should place it in its depression.

hebrew_text: אַמֵּימָר מַתְנֵי לַהּ מִפְּנֵי שֶׁנִּרְאֶה כְּעוֹדֵר, וְקַשְׁיָא לֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה אַדְּרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה: וּמִי אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה כׇּל שֶׁנִּרְאֶה כְּעוֹדֵר אָסוּר?
human_translation: Ameimar would teach because it appears as if he were hoeing and he a difficulty between Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya and Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya. Did Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya say any that appear as if he were hoeing is prohibited?
llm_translation: Ammemar teaches her because she appears like a flock, and it is difficult for Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah to respond to Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah. And who said Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah, "Anyone who appears like a flock is forbidden?"

hebrew_text: וּרְמִינְהִי: עוֹשֶׂה אָדָם אֶת זִבְלוֹ אוֹצָר. רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹסֵר, עַד שֶׁיַּעֲמִיק שְׁלֹשָׁה טְפָחִים, אוֹ עַד שֶׁיַּגְבִּיהַּ שְׁלֹשָׁה טְפָחִים. הָיָה לוֹ דָּבָר מוּעָט — מוֹסִיף עָלָיו וְהוֹלֵךְ.
human_translation: raise a contradiction A person his manure becomes a storage Rabbi Meir prohibits unless he deepens three handbreadths or raises three handbreadths he had a small amount he may continue to add to it,
llm_translation: And they raised a dilemma: Does a person make his dung heap a storehouse? Rabbi Meir prohibits until he deepens it three handbreadths, or until he raises it three handbreadths. If he had a small amount — he adds to it and it continues.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה אוֹסֵר עַד שֶׁיַּעְמִיק שְׁלֹשָׁה אוֹ עַד שֶׁיַּגְבִּיהַּ שְׁלֹשָׁה, אוֹ עַד שֶׁיִּתֵּן עַל הַסֶּלַע!
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya prohibits unless he deepens three or he raises three above or he places on a rock.
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah prohibits until he deepens three or until he raises three, or until he places it on the rock!

hebrew_text: רַבִּי זֵירָא וְרַבִּי אַבָּא בַּר מֶמֶל, חַד אָמַר: כְּגוֹן שֶׁהֶעֱמִיק, וְחַד אָמַר: זִיבְלוֹ מוֹכִיחַ עָלָיו.
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira and Rabbi Abba bar Memel One said: where he deepened And one said: His manure is proof
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira and Rabbi Abba bar Memel, one said: "For example, when he delved deep," and one said: "His garment testifies against him."

hebrew_text: וּמְתַקְּנִין אֶת הַמְקוּלְקֶלֶת בַּמּוֹעֵד. מַאי מְקוּלְקֶלֶת? אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא: שֶׁאִם הָיְתָה עֲמוּקָּה טֶפַח — מַעֲמִידָהּ עַל שִׁשָּׁה טְפָחִים.
human_translation: One may repair a damaged during a Festival. What is a damaged Rabbi Abba said that if it was a handbreadth deep he sets it at six handbreadths.
llm_translation: And they fix the m'kulkelet in the festival. What is m'kulkelet? Rabbi Abba said: If it was a tefach deep - they stand it on six tefachim.

hebrew_text: פְּשִׁיטָא, חֲצִי טֶפַח עַל שְׁלֹשָׁה טְפָחִים, כֵּיוָן דְּלָא עָבַר מַיָּא — לָא כְּלוּם הוּא. טִפְחַיִים עַל שְׁנֵים עָשָׂר, דְּקָא טָרַח טִירְחָא יַתִּירָא — לָא.
human_translation: obvious half a handbreadth of three handbreadths, since water does not flow it is nothing two handbreadths to twelve handbreadths, since it involves excessive exertion, no,
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Peshita, half a handbreadth on three handbreadths, since it did not pass over water - it is not considered a vessel. A handbreadth on twelve, because he exerted extra effort - no."

hebrew_text: טִפְחַיִים עַל שִׁבְעָה מַהוּ? הָכָא חֲמִשָּׁה קָא מַעֲמֵיק, וְהָכָא חֲמִשָּׁה קָא מַעֲמֵיק, אוֹ דִלְמָא: כֵּיוָן דְּאִיכָּא טֶפַח יַתִּירָא — אִיכָּא טִירְחָא טְפֵי? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: two handbreadths to seven what is Here, he deepens five and here, he deepen five Or perhaps, since there is an extra handbreadth involves greater effort, shall stand
llm_translation: Palms over seven what? Here, five is deepening, and here, five is deepening, or perhaps: since there is an extra handbreadth - is there more exertion? This remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: אַבָּיֵי שְׁרָא לִבְנֵי בַּר הַמְדָּךְ לְשַׁחוֹפֵי נַהֲרָא. רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה שְׁרָא לְהוּ לִבְנֵי סָכוּתָא לְמִיכְרֵא נַהֲרָא טְמִימָא. רַב אָשֵׁי שְׁרָא לְהוּ לִבְנֵי מָתָא מַחְסֵיָא לְאַקְדּוֹחֵי נְהַר בּוּרְנִיץ. אֲמַר: כֵּיוָן דְּשָׁתוּ מִינֵּיהּ רַבִּים — כְּרַבִּים דָּמֵי, וּתְנַן: עוֹשִׂין כׇּל צוֹרְכֵי רַבִּים.
human_translation: Abaye permitted the people of Bar Hamdakh to remove the river Rabbi Yirmeya permitted the people of Sekhavta to dredge out a river that had become blocked. Rav Ashi permitted the people of Mata Meḥasya, to clean out the Burnitz River. He said: Since the public drinks from it, it is considered like a public and we learned one may tend to all public needs
llm_translation: Abaye permitted the sons of Bar Hamdach to rinse in the river. Rabbi Yirmeya permitted the sons of Sakutha to sell fish in the river Tmima. Rav Ashi permitted the people of Mata Machseya to dig channels in the river Burnitz. He said: Once many benefit from it, it is considered as if many benefit, and we learned: One may do all the needs of the public.

hebrew_text: וּמְתַקְּנִין אֶת
human_translation: one may repair
llm_translation: And they fix the...

hebrew_text: קִילְקוּלֵי הַמַּיִם שֶׁבִּרְשׁוּת הָרַבִּים וְכוּ׳. חֲטִיטָה — אִין, חֲפִירָה — לָא.
human_translation: damaged water in the public domain and Cleaning is digging is not
llm_translation: The mixing of water in a public domain, etc. Wheat - no, digging - yes.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא שֶׁאֵין רַבִּים צְרִיכִין לָהֶם, אֲבָל רַבִּים צְרִיכִין לָהֶם — אֲפִילּוּ חֲפִירָה מוּתָּר.
human_translation: Rabbi Ya’akov said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: They taught only when the public does not need them; but if the public needs them, even digging is permitted.
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Yaakov said Rabbi Yochanan: They taught not except that many do not need them, but many need them - even digging is permitted.

hebrew_text: וְכִי רַבִּים צְרִיכִין לָהֶם מִי שְׁרֵי? וְהָתַנְיָא: חוֹטְטִין בּוֹרוֹת שִׁיחִין וּמְעָרוֹת שֶׁל יָחִיד, וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר שֶׁל רַבִּים, וְאֵין חוֹפְרִין בּוֹרוֹת שִׁיחִין וּמְעָרוֹת שֶׁל רַבִּים, וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר שֶׁל יָחִיד. מַאי לָאו, בְּשֶׁרַבִּים צְרִיכִין לָהֶם?!
human_translation: And when the public needs them, is permitted? But isn’t it taught One may clean cisterns, ditches, and caves of an individual and, needless to say, of the public. But one may not dig cisterns, ditches, or caves of the public and, needless to say, of an individual. What, is it not where the public needs them,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And do many need a scribe for them? And it was taught: One may line pits, ditches, and caves of an individual, needless to say of many, but one may not line pits, ditches, and caves of many, needless to say of an individual. What is the reason that many do not need a scribe for them?!

hebrew_text: לָא, בְּשֶׁאֵין רַבִּים צְרִיכִין לָהֶם.
human_translation: No, where the public does not need them.
llm_translation: No, when many do not need them.

hebrew_text: דִּכְווֹתַהּ גַּבֵּי יָחִיד, שֶׁאֵין יָחִיד צָרִיךְ לָהֶם, חֲטִיטָה מִי שְׁרֵי? וְהָתַנְיָא: בּוֹרוֹת שִׁיחִין וּמְעָרוֹת שֶׁל יָחִיד — כּוֹנְסִין מַיִם לְתוֹכָן, אֲבָל לֹא חוֹטְטִין וְלֹא שָׁפִין אֶת סִדְקֵיהֶן. וְשֶׁל רַבִּים — חוֹטְטִין אוֹתָן וְשָׁפִין אֶת סִדְקֵיהֶן.
human_translation: in the corresponding with regard to an individual, the individual does not need them. is cleaning permitted? Isn’t it taught One may gather water into cisterns, ditches, and caves of an individual, but one may not clean or plaster their cracks; but of the public, one may clean and plaster their cracks?
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: Regarding a pit belonging to an individual, since an individual does not need them, is it permitted to sow flax seeds in it? And it was taught: Regarding pits of an individual - one may collect water in them, but one may not dig or smooth their walls. But regarding pits of the public - one may dig and smooth their walls.

hebrew_text: וְאֶלָּא מַאי — בְּשֶׁיָּחִיד צָרִיךְ לָהֶם? דִּכְווֹתַהּ גַּבֵּי רַבִּים, בְּשֶׁרַבִּים צְרִיכִין לָהֶם, חֲפִירָה מִי אֲסִיר? וְהָתַנְיָא: בּוֹרוֹת שִׁיחִין וּמְעָרוֹת שֶׁל יָחִיד — כּוֹנְסִין מַיִם לְתוֹכָן וְחוֹטְטִין אוֹתָן, אֲבָל לֹא שָׁפִין אֶת סִדְקֵיהֶן, וְלֹא חוֹטְטִין לְתוֹכָן, וְלֹא סָדִין אוֹתָן בְּסִיד. וְשֶׁל רַבִּים — חוֹפְרִין אוֹתָן, וְסָדִין אוֹתָן בְּסִיד!
human_translation: Rather, what where the individual needs in the corresponding with regard to the public, the public needs them. is digging prohibited? Isn’t it taught One may gather water into cisterns, ditches, and caves of an individual, and one may clean them but one may not plaster their cracks, clear into them lime them with lime But of the public, one may dig them out and lime them with lime.
llm_translation: And rather what — in that a private individual needs them? For it is common regarding the public, in that the public needs them, is digging prohibited? But it was taught: Cisterns of individuals and caves of individuals — they gather water into them and stir them, but they do not plaster their cracks, and they do not stir them inside, and they do not plaster them with lime. And those of the public — they dig them, and they plaster them with lime!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא קַשְׁיָא הָךְ קַמַּיְיתָא! תָּרֵיץ הָכִי: חוֹטְטִין בּוֹרוֹת שֶׁל יָחִיד בְּשֶׁיָּחִיד צָרִיךְ לָהֶם, וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר בְּשֶׁל רַבִּים כְּשֶׁרַבִּים צְרִיכִין לָהֶם, דַּאֲפִילּוּ חֲפִירָה מוּתָּר.
human_translation: But the first difficult, Answer as follows: One may clean cisterns, of an individual when the individual needs them; and needless to say, of the public when the public needs them, as even digging is permitted
llm_translation: Rather, the question is difficult! Resolve it thus: One who digs pits of an individual within the property of an individual requires them, and needless to say, when it comes to pits of the public, as the public needs them, for even digging is permitted.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין חוֹפְרִין בּוֹרוֹת שִׁיחִין וּמְעָרוֹת שֶׁל רַבִּים — בְּשֶׁאֵין רַבִּים צְרִיכִין לָהֶם, וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר שֶׁל יָחִיד, דְּכִי אֵין יָחִיד צָרִיךְ לָהֶם — אֲפִילּוּ חֲטִיטָה נָמֵי אָסוּר.
human_translation: But one may not dig cisterns, ditches and caves for the public when the public does not need them. And needless to say, for an individual, as when an individual does not need even cleaning them is prohibited.
llm_translation: And one does not dig wells, ditches, and caves of the public - when the public does not need them, and needless to say of an individual, for when an individual does not need them - even a clod of earth is prohibited.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: מַתְנִיתִין נָמֵי דַּיְקָא, דְּקָתָנֵי: עוֹשִׂין כׇּל צוֹרְכֵי רַבִּים, ״כׇּל״ לְאֵתוֹיֵי מַאי — לָאו לְאֵתוֹיֵי חֲפִירָה?
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: the mishna is also precise, As it teaches: One may tend to all public needs. What all to add Does it not to add the digging
llm_translation: Rav Ashe said: The Mishnah also supports this, as it teaches: They make all the needs of the public. "All" - to include what? - Is it not to include digging?

hebrew_text: לָא, לְאֵתוֹיֵי הָא דְּתַנְיָא: יוֹצְאִין לְקַוֵּוץ אֶת הַדְּרָכִים, וּלְתַקֵּן אֶת הָרְחוֹבוֹת וְאֶת הָאִסְטְרָטָאוֹת, וְלָמוֹד אֶת הַמִּקְוָאוֹת. וְכׇל מִקְוֶה שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ אַרְבָּעִים סְאָה מַרְגִּילִין לְתוֹכוֹ, אַרְבָּעִים סְאָה.
human_translation: No, to add that which is taught go out to clear thorns from the road, and to repair the streets and highways [ isterata’ot ], and to measure the ritual baths And any ritual bath does not contain forty se’a , they direct [ margilin ] into it, forty se’a
llm_translation: Not to, for the purpose of that which was taught: They go out to uproot thorns from the roads, and to repair the streets and the alleys, and to study the Scriptures. And any ritual bath that does not contain forty se'ah, they habituate within it, forty se'ah.

hebrew_text: וּמִנַּיִן שֶׁאִם לֹא יָצְאוּ וְעָשׂוּ כׇּל אֵלּוּ, שֶׁכׇּל דָּמִים שֶׁנִּשְׁפְּכוּ שָׁם מַעֲלֶה עֲלֵיהֶם הַכָּתוּב כְּאִילּוּ הֵם שְׁפָכוּם — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְהָיָה עָלֶיךָ דָּמִים״.
human_translation: And from where that if did not go out and do all these that any blood that is shed there the verse ascribes to them as if they had shed it? The verse states and so blood be upon you”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And from where do we know that if they did not go out and perform all these rituals, that all the blood that was spilled there, the Scripture ascribes it to them as if they spilled it? The Scripture teaches: "And it shall be upon you blood."

hebrew_text: הָא בְּהֶדְיָא קָתָנֵי לַהּ: וּמְתַקְּנִין אֶת הַדְּרָכִים וְאֶת הָרְחוֹבוֹת וְאֶת הַמִּקְוָאוֹת. וְעוֹשִׂין כׇּל צוֹרְכֵי רַבִּים לְאֵתוֹיֵי מַאי — לָאו לְאֵתוֹיֵי חֲפִירָה? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: But are explicitly taught One may repair the roads, streets, and ritual baths, and one may tend to all public needs. What to add? Does it not add the digging Conclude from this
llm_translation: Here is the English translation of the Talmudic text: "This was taught in the city of Hedya: 'And they repair the roads, the streets, and the mikvaot. And they fulfill all the needs of the public for what? — Not for digging? Learn from this."

hebrew_text: מְצַיְּנִין אֶת הַקְּבָרוֹת. אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי: רֶמֶז לְצִיּוּן קְבָרוֹת מִן הַתּוֹרָה מִנַּיִן, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְרָאָה עֶצֶם אָדָם וּבָנָה אֶצְלוֹ צִיּוּן״.
human_translation: One may mark graves Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said: Where is there an allusion in the Torah to the marking of graves? The verse states: and any see a man’s bone, then shall he set up a sign by it”
llm_translation: We mark the graves. Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said: From where do we derive a hint for marking graves from the Torah? The verse states: "And a man shall see a bone and build beside it a marker."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: הָא מִקַּמֵּי דְּלֵיתֵי יְחֶזְקֵאל, מַאן אֲמַר? וְלִיטַעְמָיךְ, הָא דְּאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: דָּבָר זֶה, מִתּוֹרַת מֹשֶׁה רַבֵּינוּ לֹא לָמַדְנוּ, מִדִּבְרֵי יְחֶזְקֵאל בֶּן בּוּזִי לָמַדְנוּ: ״כׇּל בֶּן נֵכָר עֶרֶל לֵב וְעֶרֶל בָּשָׂר לֹא יָבֹא אֶל מִקְדָּשִׁי לְשָׁרְתֵנִי״ —
human_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Before Ezekiel came who said And according to your reasoning, this that Rav Ḥisda said. This matter we did not learn from the Torah of Moses our teacher, we learned from the words of Ezekiel ben Buzi, “No stranger, uncircumcised in heart, or uncircumcised in flesh, shall enter into My Sanctuary to serve Me”
llm_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: From where is it derived that if one does not have the book of Ezekiel, who said it? And to support you, this is what Rav Ḥisda said: We did not learn this matter from the Torah of Moses our teacher, but we learned it from the words of Ezekiel son of Buzi: "No foreigner, uncircumcised in heart and uncircumcised in flesh, shall enter My sanctuary to serve Me."

hebrew_text: מִקַּמֵּי דְּלֵיתֵי יְחֶזְקֵאל, מַאן אֲמַר? אֶלָּא גְּמָרָא גְּמִירִי לַהּ וַאֲתָא יְחֶזְקֵאל וְאַסְמְכַהּ אַקְּרָא, הָכָא נָמֵי: גְּמָרָא גְּמִירִי לַהּ, וַאֲתָא יְחֶזְקֵאל וְאַסְמְכַהּ אַקְּרָא.
human_translation: Before Ezekiel came, who said Rather, they learned it as a tradition and Ezekiel came and based it on a verse. Here too, they learned it as a tradition, and Ezekiel came and based it on a verse.
llm_translation: Before Ezekiel was born, who said it? Rather, the Gemara learned it and Ezekiel came and supported it with a verse, here it is stated: the Gemara learned it, and Ezekiel came and supported it with a verse.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ אָמַר, מֵהָכָא: ״וְטָמֵא טָמֵא יִקְרָא״ — טוּמְאָה קוֹרְאָה לוֹ וְאוֹמֶרֶת לוֹ ״פְּרוֹשׁ״. וְכֵן אָמַר רַבִּי עוּזִּיאֵל בַּר בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי עוּזִּיאֵל רַבָּה: טוּמְאָה קוֹרְאָהּ לוֹ וְאוֹמֶרֶת לוֹ ״פְּרוֹשׁ״.
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu said: from here: shall cry: Impure, impure” impurity cries out and tells him: Remove yourself. And similarly, Rabbi Uzziel, grandson of Rabbi Uzziel the Great, said: Impurity cries out and tells him: Remove yourself.
llm_translation: Rabbi Avahu said, from here: "And the impure one shall call out, impure, impure" - impurity calls out to him and says to him "Separate." And so said Rabbi Uzziel the son of Rabbi Uzziel the Great: impurity calls out to him and says to him "Separate."

hebrew_text: וְהַאי לְהָכִי הוּא דַּאֲתָא? הַהוּא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְכִדְתַנְיָא: ״וְטָמֵא טָמֵא יִקְרָא״. צָרִיךְ לְהוֹדִיעַ צַעֲרוֹ לְרַבִּים, וְרַבִּים מְבַקְּשִׁין עָלָיו רַחֲמִים!
human_translation: But this does it come to teach this That is needed for that which is taught “And he shall cry: Impure, impure”; must inform the public of his distress, and the public will pray for mercy on his behalf.
llm_translation: This is why he came? That one wants to teach him according to what is taught: "And the impure shall be impure." It is necessary to inform his suffering to many, and many seek mercy for him!

hebrew_text: אִם כֵּן, לִיכְתּוֹב: ״וְטָמֵא יִקְרָא״, מַאי ״וְטָמֵא טָמֵא״ — שָׁמְעַתְּ מִינַּהּ תַּרְתֵּי.
human_translation: If it is so let it write: And he shall cry: Impure. What impure, impure? Learn from this two
llm_translation: If so, it should be written: "And the impure shall call," what is "and the impure is impure" - you have heard two from it.

hebrew_text: אַבָּיֵי אָמַר, מֵהָכָא: ״וְלִפְנֵי עִוֵּר לֹא תִתֵּן מִכְשׁוֹל״. רַב פָּפָּא אָמַר: ״וְאָמַר סֹלּוּ סֹלּוּ פַּנּוּ דָרֶךְ״.
human_translation: Abaye said: from here, “You shall not put a stumbling block before the blind” Rav Pappa said “And He will say: Pave, pave, clear the way,
llm_translation: Abaye said, from here: "And before the blind do not place a stumbling block." Rav Papa said, "And he said, 'Clear, clear the way for his path.'"

hebrew_text: רַב חִינָּנָא אָמַר: ״הָרִימוּ מִכְשׁוֹל מִדֶּרֶךְ עַמִּי״. רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אִידִי אָמַר: ״וְהוֹדַעְתָּ לָהֶם אֶת הַדֶּרֶךְ אֲשֶׁר יֵלְכוּ בָהּ״.
